TEXT: CARDINAL . NORP The applicant , Mr NORP , is a NORP national , who was born in DATE and lives in Rīga .
CARDINAL . NORP The facts of the case , as submitted by the applicant , may be summarised as follows .
CARDINAL . Background information

CARDINAL . During the municipal elections of DATE the election results in CARDINAL of the municipalities were annulled because the election procedure had been breached . Shortly before new elections took place in DATE , the authorities carried out an investigative operation involving phone tapping . P. , a candidate in the elections , was among those whose telephone conversations were recorded . He was head of a company which , at about the same time , had been unexpectedly inspected by the tax authorities ( ORG PERSON policija ) . The police discovered various shortcomings in the company ’s accounting records as well as alleged tax evasion , and criminal proceedings were instituted .
CARDINAL . Criminal proceedings leading to the order to disclose journalist ’s source ( first set of proceedings )

CARDINAL . On DATE the newspaper “ PERSON ” published an article entitled “ Scandal . [ Political ] party ’s black money cash - box discovered ? ” ( “ Skandāls . PERSON atklāta partijas melnā kase ? ” ) . It contained , inter alia , transcripts of PERSON ’s telephone conversations recorded in DATE . The conversations reflected PERSON ’s attempts to use his political contacts to settle a problem with the tax authorities . The conversations also raised questions as to the unofficial financing of the political party of which P. was a member .

CARDINAL . The published telephone conversations had been obtained in the course of an investigative operation carried out by ORG ( Drošības policija ) and were therefore considered as classified operational information . On DATE the Security Police instituted criminal proceedings under section CARDINAL of the Criminal Law for breach of confidentiality . No charges were brought .
CARDINAL . It appears from the case - file that the investigating authorities searched the office of the newspaper concerned and seized an audiotape of the impugned conversations .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant , who was a journalist at the aforementioned newspaper and the author of the article , was asked by ORG to give a statement in the criminal proceedings . Invoking his journalist ’s privileges , the applicant refused to disclose the source of the recorded telephone conversations .

CARDINAL . Following a request by ORG , on DATE the investigative judge of ORG , after having heard the prosecutor and the applicant , upheld the part of the request concerning the disclosure of the source of the published telephone conversations .

CARDINAL . On DATE the Rīga City ORG dismissed an appeal lodged by the applicant . The judge noted , inter alia , that the investigation into the breach of confidentiality had not identified any suspects and therefore had not established at what level those responsible for disclosing the classified information had accessed it . The decision stated that even if other means of investigating could have been deployed , in a period when GPE was preparing to host a NATO summit the persistence of the aforementioned criminal activities could have put public safety and national security at risk . It concluded that it had been an exceptional situation and that the restrictions of the rights of an individual were proportional to the protection of the public interests .
CARDINAL . The court also noted that the investigating judge had only partly upheld the request of ORG .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG dismissed a request submitted by the applicant to terminate the criminal proceedings in which the applicant had to give statements ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) . It explained inter alia , that the criminal proceedings had been instituted not as a result of the publication of the tapped telephone conversations but because of a breach of confidentiality committed by an individual who had been entrusted with the information in the course of his or her official duties . The letter further noted that the sole aim of the request to divulge the journalist ’s source was to identify the official responsible for the breach of confidentiality . The response could be appealed against to ORG .

CARDINAL . On DATE the Security Police asked the applicant to execute the court order of CARDINAL DATE . The applicant was also informed about possible criminal liability under LAW of LAW in the event of non - compliance with the order . The applicant again refused to disclose the information , invoking his rights as a journalist as well as the right against self - incrimination .

CARDINAL . In a letter dated DATE the Security Police again asked the applicant to submit the information . They also explained that he had the status of a witness in the respective criminal proceedings , so his testimonies could not be used against him and his argument in that respect was unfounded . In his response , the applicant confirmed his refusal to disclose the source .
CARDINAL . Criminal proceedings against the applicant for non - compliance with the court order to disclose the source ( second set of proceedings )
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was charged under section CARDINAL of LAW for refusal to comply with a court order .

CARDINAL . On DATE the Rīga City Centre District Court found the applicant guilty and fined him CARDINAL lati ( ORG ) ( MONEY ( ORG ) ) . The court noted that the intentional nature of the offence had been proven by the fact that the applicant had refused to give witness statements in the first set of criminal proceedings . The court concluded that the obligation imposed on the applicant by the court order was not contrary to the second paragraph of LAW in that by complying with the order the applicant would have prevented a criminal offence from being committed .

CARDINAL . The appellate court upheld the lower court ’s judgment . It noted that in the first set of criminal proceedings the applicant ’s journalistic immunity had been overridden by the court order of DATE . The applicant had been aware of the procedural obligation imposed on him by the court order and therefore his refusal to obey had constituted the mens rea required for the offence provided for under LAW of LAW . The appellate court noted that the proportionality of the measure had already been measured at the time of issuing the order . In addition , judging from the responses of ORG found in the case file and the investigation in the first set of criminal proceedings , the appellate court concluded that ORG had had no other means of disclosing the source of the information .

CARDINAL . In his appeal on points of law the applicant argued that his activities could not be qualified under LAW of LAW as there was a lack of intention on his part . He also relied on a recommendation of ORG and contended that the court order had not been proportional .

CARDINAL . By virtue of sections CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) and CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) of LAW , the ORG of ORG of its own motion extended the limits of the appeal on points of law and found that ORG and the lower courts had wrongfully interpreted and applied section CARDINAL of LAW . In particular , the aforementioned provision provided for criminal liability for the non - execution of judgments or decisions if the execution fell within an individual ’s official duties . As that qualification did not apply to the applicant , there was no legal basis for applying the above provision to his non - compliance with the court order . The ORG revoked the lower court ’s decision and terminated the criminal proceedings .

CARDINAL . In DATE the applicant asked ORG whether , based on the outcome of the aforementioned criminal proceedings , it would publicly apologise to him , and whether measures had been taken in order to avoid similar situations in the future . In response , ORG indicated that :

“ ... [ t]he Criminal Procedure Law provides for an acquittal or conviction , ... the law does not provide for an obligation on the part of the prosecutor to apologise to someone for having brought charges in proceedings which resulted in an acquittal . ”

CARDINAL . The applicant was informed by ORG his right to institute civil proceedings for non - pecuniary damages in accordance with ORG caused by ORG ( ORG izziņas izdarītāja , prokurora vai tiesneša nelikumīgas vai nepamatotas rīcības rezultātā nodarīto zaudējumu atlīdzināšanu ) .
B. Relevant domestic and international law
CARDINAL . Criminal Law

CARDINAL . NORP In accordance with CARDINAL , a person who intentionally discloses an official secret , having been warned about the consequences of disclosure but where the offence does not involve espionage , may be sentenced to CARDINAL eight years’ imprisonment or receive a fine not exceeding the minimum monthly salary .

CARDINAL . By virtue of section CARDINAL , a person who intentionally fails to execute a court judgment or decision , or delays the execution thereof , will be subject to a fine not exceeding CARDINAL minimum DATE salaries .
CARDINAL . Criminal Procedure Law

CARDINAL . Under section CARDINAL of GPE ( as in force at the material time ) , a court may order a journalist or editor to indicate the source of published information . An investigating judge will decide on the proposal of an investigator or public prosecutor , having listened to the submitter of the proposal , or a journalist or editor , and having familiarised him or herself with the materials of the case . An investigating judge will take a decision on the indication of the source of information , giving due consideration to the proportionality of the rights of the person and the public interests . The decision may be challenged against to the chairman of the court whose decision is final .
CARDINAL . Law on the Press and Other ORG

CARDINAL . NORP Under LAW , journalists may choose not to indicate the source of their information . If the person who has provided the information requests that his or her name is not to be indicated , this request shall be binding upon the editorial board . The source of information may be revealed only at the request of a court or prosecutor .
CARDINAL . Law on Compensation for Damage caused by ORG ( ORG izziņas izdarītāja , prokurora vai tiesneša nelikumīgas vai nepamatotas rīcības rezultātā nodarīto zaudējumu atlīdzināšanu )

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL of the Law on Compensation for Damage caused by ORG deals with the unlawful conduct of investigative bodies , ORG and the courts and provides that pecuniary and non - pecuniary damages may be awarded , inter alia , in the event of an acquittal for reasons of rehabilitation . Requests for pecuniary damages in the event of an acquittal by the court must be submitted to ORG . In relation to non - pecuniary damages , a person has the right to submit a civil claim to a court of general jurisdiction .
CARDINAL . Civil PERSON ( Civillikums )

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL provides that a judge must be guided by the general principles of law and justice when a court is called upon to adjudicate on its own discretion or when exceptional circumstances have to be taken into account .
CARDINAL . Recommendation No . R ( DATE ) CARDINAL of ORG on the right of journalists not to disclose their sources of information ( adopted on DATE )
CARDINAL . Principle CARDINAL ( Limits to the right of non - disclosure )

“ a. The right of journalists not to disclose information identifying a source must not be subject to other restrictions than those mentioned in LAW , paragraph CARDINAL of the Convention . In determining whether a legitimate interest in a disclosure falling within the scope of LAW , paragraph CARDINAL of the Convention outweighs the public interest in not disclosing information identifying a source , competent authorities of member states shall pay particular regard to the importance of the right of non - disclosure and the pre - eminence given to it in the case - law of ORG , and may only order a disclosure if , subject to paragraph b , there exists an overriding requirement in the public interest and if circumstances are of a sufficiently vital and serious nature .
b. The disclosure of information identifying a source should not be deemed necessary unless it can be convincingly established that :
i. reasonable alternative measures to the disclosure do not exist or have been exhausted by the persons or public authorities that seek the disclosure , and
ii . the legitimate interest in the disclosure clearly outweighs the public interest in the non - disclosure , bearing in mind that :
- an overriding requirement of the need for disclosure is proved ,
- the circumstances are of a sufficiently vital and serious nature ,
- the necessity of the disclosure is identified as responding to a pressing social need , and
- member states enjoy a certain margin of appreciation in assessing this need , but this margin goes hand in hand with the supervision by ORG .
c. The above requirements should be applied at all stages of any proceedings where the right of non - disclosure might be invoked . ”
